Award.AwardTitle: Research Vessel for Everett Community College
Award.AbstractNarration:
Everett Community College (EvCC) is awarded a grant to acquire a research vessel to enhance undergraduate research experiences for community college students and other educational partners in the North Puget Sound region. This research vessel provides the platform to conduct basic biological research relevant to two local community college education agendas, leveraging new levels of academic and scientific collaboration. Providing opportunities for students to explore the intersection between research and education while dissecting the biological connections to physical and geological dynamics in an estuary represents powerful teaching and learning.

The vessel will be equipped with a drop down bow for beach landing and swing through davit access for a CTD array and sediment dredge, as well as electronic interface for real-time display of water column profile and benthic surveys. The vessel will expand and enhance the research capacity on longitudinal research conducted by students, increasing research cruises from monthly to weekly, while providing greater research training opportunities for more students. A dedicated research vessel provides flexibility to adjust to weather conditions, allows for anchoring, provides shallow water access for eel grass surveys, increases data collection as well as accessibility, increases collaboration between community colleges, universities and state agencies and provides increased opportunities for community engagement.

Emerging partnerships expand the research opportunities beyond EvCC, through the partner institutions of the Community College Undergraduate Research Initiative. Ongoing partnerships with local universities, state agencies, K-12 institutions and community partners provide rich opportunities for increasing the sense of place and the connection to the local ecosystem which helps students make more informed decisions about the environment in which they live. By providing the tools and access, this vessel represents an innovative platform for teaching and training emerging scientists, many of whom are underserved in STEM fields. For more information visit www.everettcc.edu/orca

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of designing and building a research vessel to enhance undergraduate research training and experiences for community college students was accomplished. The utilization of the research vessel has transformed the research experience for the target students. In less than one year of operation (through September 2015), the R/V Phocoena operated 56 days, conducting undergraduate research in Possession Sound. The ship’s manifest documents a total of 548 students and observers experienced a research cruise first hand, building confidence in the nature of science applied to the local region with an awareness of the ecosystem in which they live.  The intellectual merit is realized on every cruise, where students receive direct, hands-on experience with oceanographic equipment as they sample multiple parameters that contribute to the longitudinal, ten-year study of the State of Possession Sound. Students from three different community colleges have utilized the vessel for research.

 

The Research Vessel Phocoena was delivered to Everett, Wa October 18, 2014. The next two weeks were spent training crew and establishing and meeting the criteria for Coast Guard designation as a research vessel. A dedication event was planned and held with over 200 attendees including local elected officials and community members (http://www.heraldnet.com/article/20141121/NEWS01/141129826). This vessel is the platform for research cruises to support the data collection for the State of Possession Sound, a multi-year project initiated by the PI that has been collecting longitudinal biogeochemical data in the region for more than ten years.

 

Underserved students that may not have an opportunity to participate in research have the chance to do so on this vessel. An innovative approach within the local community emerged by designing and hosting a week long “camp” for local YMCA My Achievers Program (MAP) participants. MAP was designed to eliminate the achievement gap students may face due to racial/ethnic barriers, immigration status and socio-economic factors. Traditionally an afterschool program, the PI and YMCA executive director pioneered a week long camp designed to reduce summer learning loss and to increase interest in STEM fields.  Research experiences through mentoring helps students see themselves engaged in science. Sample quotes from the ORCA student mentors include:

  1. “Being able to work on the boat and do hands-on work with other students.”
  2. “It was really cool to have such a hands-on way of learning. SO much better than reading from a textbook!”
  3. “Getting to do real science not little “experiments” in a classroom like in high school.”

The MAP camp participants reported:

  1. “My favorite part of the program was the boat trip because it was amazing being on the ocean and seeing sea lions and harbor seals.”
  2. “My favorite part of this program was the mentors that made me feel welcomed.”
  3. “My favorite part was taking the plankton tow.”

 

The strength and quality of the undergraduate research experience is enhanced by this grant for a research vessel. The engagement of student research early in the career represents a viable, adaptable pedagogical model.
